bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., April 1, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Rath that Rojas and Cabrera have invited Rath to visit their farm. Hench writes that the two women are especially concerned about their property due to the recent revolution in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., April 1, 1952
div1.opener:
April 1, 1952
Mr. Frederick L. Rath, Jr., Director
National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings
712 Jackson Place, N.W.
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Mr. Rath:
div1.p:
I enclose a letter and a translation thereof which I have just re-
ceived from my friend, Senora Maria Rojas of the Finca San Jose,
Calzada Real y Gomez Redencion, Quemados de Marianao, Havana. You
will see that the recent revolution has disturbed her greatly and
no wonder, as people in her situation have nothing to gain and every-
thing to lose by national instability.

“Tina” Rojas has always been so modest. She speaks English quite well
but because her companion, Lydia, speaks English practically like an
American, Tina has always had an inferiority complex about it. There-
fore I am not surprised that she is asking me to convey to you her in-
vitation to visit them. Please, therefore, if you can do so, plan to
visit them as you and I discussed. May I suggest that you keep the
matter of the financial arrangement between you and me confidential.
Because I think that you would be getting off to a very fine start with
them if you were under no obligation to them. If it is necessary for
you to visit them again (and it may well be) then perhaps we can diplo-
matically suggest that your budget does not allow a trip at that particu-
lar time, etc., etc., but that if they saw fit etc., etc. Keep a list of
your expenses from Florida to Havana and I shall be glad to send you a
check for it and shall be pleased to be allowed to consider it as a
charitable contribution to your organization. I think that now, even
more than before the revolution, they are anxious to have some advice.

Would you kindly write them at your earliest convenience so that they will
know you are coming as they will wish to give you their full time while
you are there and will not want to make other social engagements which
they might have to break.

I think I left with you enough reprints giving you the background so that
you will know why their finca and Camp Lazear bear such an important re-
lationship with each other and bring in Finlay as well as Reed and the
Americans.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
